99304.name: International Business
99304.description:
From the back of the box:

"A game of buying and selling
Banking
Mortgaging
etc."

A little later...

"International Business is well known worldwide with different names. This is an evergreen game where you act as a foreign businessman who buy or sell properties in famous countries of world. You also get an idea to deal with another person. So, let play & ready to prove himself, the wealthiest person of the world."

Poor grammar is from the back of the box.

The game itself has a lot ripped off from Monopoly with only some minor changes and totally different subject matter.

99305.name: N the Know
99305.description: This is an obscure Trivia game that tests you knowledge about topics from Kwanzaa to Egyptian history. It gives a very narrow slice of what the author thought people should know with a slant towards African, Egyptian, and African-American history.

99306.name: Shamu and his Crew, Protect Our Seas Game
99306.description:
From the back of the box:

"Go on an ocean voyage with Shamu and his friends!

Get ready for a spectacular journey where you will help brng Shamu's friends to safety! In this exciting game, you'll have fun as you learn about some of the dangers that face our friends who live in the seas. Dolly Dolphin is caught in a net and Pete Penguin is atop an iceberg. Baby Shamu has been beached and O.P. Otter us in an oil slick. But help is on the way!

Roll the die and send your Shamu mover across the ocean floor to the danger spaces. Once you get there, you'll be able to resuce Shamu's friends. Save them, thn move them to the dock before going onto the Funship. The first Shamu there wins!"

Features a 3-D game board.

Published in concert with Sea World.

99307.name: Signals
99307.description:
Signals: The Sneaky Card Game. Collect all 5 members of one family and your team wins.

Contents:
Instructions
20 Family Cards
40 Money Cards
4 Photo Albums

Each player gets one Photo Album, and one Money Card (dealt randomly). The player with the highest value card starts the game.

4 more Money Cards are dealt face down to each player. The remaining Money Cards are placed faced down in the center of the table.

5 Family Cards are dealt face down to each player. The start player places one Family Card face down on the table. Each player has one chance to buy this card, by placing one or more of their Money Cards face up on the table. The next player can make a higher offer or pass. (If a player passes, they may take one card from the top of the Money Card deck.) There are no rules about talking. You may say anything you want, but if you don't want the other team to know, be sneaky, use the signals.

Play continues until one player has collected all 5 members of one family.

99308.name: Hike
99308.description: In Hike, nature springs surprises and players battle for survival. Each player receives seven cards and plays one on his/her turn. When a player cannot play a card, he/she is eliminated from the hand. The player with the fewest cards leftover wins the hand, and a player can earn a bonus by playing all of his/her cards.

99309.name: Armagetron Advanced
99309.description:
Armagetron is a multiplayer game in 3d that attempts to emulate and expand on the lightcycle sequence from the movie Tron. It's an old school arcade game slung into the 21st century. Highlights include a customizable playing arena, HUD, unique graphics, and AI bots. For the more advanced player there are new game modes and a wide variety of physics settings to tweak as well.

Source: The Game Website.

99310.name: WayWord
99310.description:
Game description from the publisher:

In Tom Jolly's WayWord, players go head-to-head to score points by finding and creating the best words from the letter tiles.

WayWord is not a standard word-building game. Attempt to outmaneuver your opponents and use the special tiles to gain the advantage. Make use of your pawn to block other players from creating words.

Optional rules and the unique game play also allow for sentences and phrases to be completed and scored for points.

99311.name: Polyhedron (Issue 134 - Vol. 19, No. 1)
99311.description:
Cover art: Illustrator Hannibal King defines political harmony in Cormyr.

The theme of this issue was politics, including the credits page, which listed 'Commander-in-chief', 'Secretary of State', 'Speaker of the House', 'Special Interest Lobbyists', 'Cabinet Members', and 'White House Interns' instead of the normal titles (publisher, editor, etc.).

Featured articles:

Raam - Hotbed of Political Adventure
Introducing the Living Verge
Creating Living City Characters
Internet 101 - Missile Silos Make Keen Hideouts
Using Politics in Your Games




It also included a RPGA Network Living City Character Log Sheet on the inside front mailing cover, an order form for RPGA merchandise on the inside back mailing cover, and a list of Adventurer's Guild Retailers on the outside back mailing cover.

99312.description:
A long time ago in Europe, ages were pretty dark. The distribution of wealth back then left a lot to be desired. Greedy people banded together to take things from other people so that the rich could get richer and the poor could have even less. Twas ever thus. Step into the middle of the normal state of human affairs as a Baron or Baroness somewhere almost in Europe a long time ago. Thanks to your birth you have a lot of little people working to make you richer, and you, in turn, are doing your best to make your king even more prosperous. If you do things right, you might someday be king.

Each player starts with a Fiefdom Management card, divided into 64 squares (49 of which can have tiles played on them. Into four of these squares you deploy your Keep, in which you will put your fortification of some sort, and your soldiers. Elsewhere in your land you deploy assorted resource gatherers and buildings in an effort to grow, prosper, and score victory points. Along the way there may be wars, invasions, tournaments, taxes, and a lot of other nonsense.
99312.name: Feudality

99313.description:
(from Compass Games website:)

Proud Monster Deluxe is a Major Revision of Command's Proud Monster and Death and Destruction.

Proud Monster Deluxe is a simulation of the Russo-German War beginning with the launch of Operation Barbarossa in June of 1941, and ending in April of 1944. It is a two-player (or multi-player) strategic / operational wargame of low-to-medium complexity.

Units in Proud Monster Deluxe are typically divisions with some corps, brigades and regiments also included. Hexes are 20 miles (about 33 kilometers) across, and each turn represents about a 2 week period.


Game system

In addition to updated graphics, the major changes are Reserves and Reserve Movement phases to simulate the potential for encirclement or defensive reaction. Soviet first winter offensive rules allow the Soviets to retake parts of Russia in early 1942 as happened in history. Both sides now have offensive supply markers to show historical offensive potential and limitations. Innovative weather chits allow for weather variation without extreme weather swings biasing the game. AFV units become even more important due to AFV combat shift. Close Combat option allows for use of an alternate loss procedure and attacker advance to form a jointly-occupied hex, for example, to simulate Stalingrad's gradual fall to the Axis. The ability to fully exploit holes created by mobile assaults is limited to reserves.

The Axis forces degrade in capability over time while the Soviet forces upgrade in capability. The Axis super heavy artillery Thor and Odin, Heavy Gustav and Dora can fire before combat resolution. Besides the 1941 Free setups, 1941 historical setups are provided for both sides as well as a 1942 scenario. Seasonal offensive rules allow for special turns when special things can happen. The 2 sides show a greater disparity in capability, the Axis can do things the Soviets cannot do and vice versa. Things that work when playing the Axis may not work when playing the Soviets and vice versa.


Game components

Game components have all been improved over the originals. All graphics have been completely updated and upgraded. Counters are 9/16" and map hexes have ample space to avoid players from knocking over those stacks of counters when the fighting starts to tighten up. The four (4) maps impress upon the players the enormous expanse of the Soviet Union and the challenge for both sides to defend and overcome it. Rules are consolidated from the two original sources into one comprehensive set, with all known errata folded in, and a number of important rule changes to improve game balance and playability. In addition, the development of a definitive set of player aids will keep players playing the game instead of hunting down items in the rules.

4 maps - each map is 22"x34" with overlap
10 full sheets of 9/16" counters (2052 counters), printed both sides
1 rules book
Full color player aid charts and tables cards printed both sides on cardstock
2 6 sided dice
1 full color box and lid
99313.name: Proud Monster Deluxe

99315.description:
From Spielbox Magazine 2011 Issue #3:

Stevie Wonder is an additional leader for the 7 Wonders expansion LEADERS.
With his help, you can build a stage of your Wonder of the World; instead of paying the required number of resources, you pay the corresponding number of coins and slide Stevie under the appropriate stage face up.

The Card is only playable with 7 Wonders: Leaders Expansion for 7 Wonders
99315.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders – Stevie

99316.description: In Grimaffen, players must remember the order of animal movements or sounds and imitate them in the right order to win. Choosing from thirty round tiles in five different colors, a player rolls a colored die to see which tile is added to the those already selected. The player then mimics the pictures on the tile to suggest an elephant's trunk motion or a wolf howl or a monkey's down-turned mouth, all within this zoo theme. Since the tiles use picture cues, reading is not necessary and components are not language specific.
99316.name: Grimaffen

99318.description:
Goal: Be the first scoring 3 (10) times (soccer) - 2 players (or 2 teams)

Content: park (optional), 2 goals, 2 x 3 pieces, 1 ball, 2 x 2 sticks with integrated magnet

1. Draw starter by lot
2. Place your 3 pieces on the board (only one in the area of the goal)
3. Try to move your (magnetic) pieces with your stick - beneath the table - hitting the ball into
proper direction; this happens simultaniously
4. Move the ball into opponent's goal
(avoid any circumstances like damage, physical injury, stiff muscles...)

99324.name: Our Kings & Queens
99324.description: Promotional card game issued by an importer of tea, around 1900 to 1910. The cards are pictorial, featuring the monarchs from William the Conqueror to King Edward VII. I have no rules but it appears to be a set collecting game.

99325.name: Poetical Pot Pie or Aunt Hulda's Courtship
99325.description:
Each player takes one of one hundred and twenty cards with a quote on it by a famous author at the time. The rules have a story with blank sections and the players have to fit the correct quote into the appropriate blank. The game was devised to amuse because players (particularly children, will frequently put the wrong quote into the right blank (and vice versa).
The box says "A little fun now and then, is relished by the best of men"

99326.name: Pyramid (Volume 3, Issue 25 - Nov 2010)
99326.description:
Epic Magic

From the publisher:

Are you looking to put the magic back in your game? Are you looking for something epic? Then this month's Pyramid -- the PDF magazine for roleplayers -- gives you both, with a theme of "Epic Magic." This over-the-top arcane issue includes:


"All the Epic Ways," a description of six different methods to work high-powered magical effects into a GURPS campaign. It includes an extended example that reveals different possibilities for the Seven Songs of Apollo!
"The Skystone Castle and Other Wonders," written by David Pulver, co-author of GURPS Fourth Edition and creator of the GURPS Spaceships system. This feature uses the GURPS Spaceships system to construct three impossible feats of magic: a giant flying castle, an orichalcum dragon, and a gargantuan six-legged sphinx.
"Essential Magic," which adds 25 new and mysterious spells to the GURPS Magic system. Harness the power of phlogiston, hellfire, alkahest, and more.
"Al-Abyad's Astrolabe," an impossible artifact designed for the GURPS Banestorm setting but usable in any magical milieu. This device, straddling science and sorcery, can rearrange the stars themselves to suit the needs of the mage!
"The World Maker," an epic eldritch enigma that introduces the titular artifact and the mysterious Toymaker. Why settle for holding the world in your hand when you can grasp more than one?
"Quartermaster Mage," a look at a vital profession for building and maintaining fantasy armies. Learn the effects of GURPS Magic spells on keeping an army fed and prepared, design a GURPS mage with the quartermaster template, and meet the mighty Captain Auric of Craine (complete with GURPS stats).


In addition, this Pyramid also pulls a few other rabbits out of its hat: Murphy's Rules with Greg Hyland, Steven Marsh's Random Thought Table, and other odds and ends. When the impossible isn't enough, this issue gives you more!

99327.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 16 - 2004)
99327.description:
From publisher blurb:

An action genre that blends wonderfully into futuristic D20 Modern campaigns is the stealth-based mission. Made immensely popular in various computer/console games, few GMs have taken the time to incorporate stealth action into their game sessions. This article provides GMs with the tools necessary to sample stealth action. Scattered throughout this article are adventure hooks waiting to be expanded into full-length adventures.

99328.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 17 - 2004)
99328.description:
From publisher blurb:

This issue presents players and GMs with information on St. George including a special advanced class and the disease dragon.

99329.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 18 - 2004)
99329.description:
From publisher blurb:

This supplement expands Blood and Vigilance into the realm of the magical, providing new powers and feats for those wishing to create a master of the mystic arts. Class power lists are provided for the magic-oriented classes from the core rules as well as a host of new feats and powers designed so that a magician’s powers could enhance his control over his magic.

99330.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 19 - 2004)
99330.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Shadow Cult is an adventure seed for modern d20 games. This adventure seed draws on elements from Blood and Relics (2nd Edition) as well as Blood and Fists: Modern Martial Arts (d20 Modern Edition) to create a somewhat unique horror-martial arts role-playing experience.

99331.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 20 - 2004)
99331.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Gravity Star is a customized PL 7 escort designed to be used as a base of operations for a party of interstellar adventurers. This PDF details the starship, offers suggestions for getting your players onboard, and provides some suggestions for adventure once they’re traveling the stars.

99332.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 21 - 2004)
99332.description:
From publisher blurb:

"The Aerie" is a Darwin's World adventure for beginning level characters. This supplement also introduces a mini-setting designed to be the home base for a group of low-level characters. This home area is rich enough to allow for a host of adventures to occur in the general area, while generic enough that it could be placed almost anywhere on the Twisted Earth.

99333.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 22 - 2004)
99333.description:
From publisher blurb:

This issue details those aliens known as the grays. Includes racial statistics for grays and the half-gray template.

99334.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 23 - 2005)
99334.description:
From publisher blurb:

Hot Piece is an adventure for modern d20 games. Since the adventure revolves around investigation more than combat this adventure is suitable to a wide range of character levels, though some classes (such as Investigator) will be much handier than others.

Once the PCs have solved the mystery of the "hot piece" they can attempt to solve the problem themselves (through apprehending the suspects) and this will require 4 PCs of approximately 3rd-5th level; however, the PCs could just as easily end the adventure by calling the police, and this could be done at any level.

99336.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 24 - 2005)
99336.description:
From publisher blurb:

Escaped Terror details five monsters and a rough adventure idea for D20 Modern campaigns. Designed primarily for campaigns involving magic and the supernatural, the information in this issue of the Modern Dispatch can be used by the GM to either construct an adventure or to add to an adventure of his own design.

99337.name: King's Crossing
99337.description:
In King's Crossing, players try to navigate their King across the board to get the home space of the enemy king. The battle rages as men pieces jump one another and also freeze and trap lines of pieces that are capture later. Unable to retreat, pieces advance into an onslaught of exchanges and multicaptures.

This game is one in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

Latest updated: Version 1.2 of the rules includes an alternate set up that is similar to that of Crossing Stonehenge, and a change in the win conditions.

99338.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 25 - 2005)
99338.description:
From publisher blurb:

Shinkansen is an adventure set piece for modern d20 games. Set pieces are a concept from films: a scene or sequence with escalated stakes and production values, as appropriate to the genre. For instance, in an action film, a set piece might be a helicopter chase amid skyscrapers. In a musical, a set piece might be a show-stopping dance number. In a comedy, a set piece might find the claustrophobic hero on an increasingly crowded bus, until he can’t take it anymore. Done right, set pieces are moments you remember weeks after seeing a movie...memorable
nuggets that become the highlights of the tale.

In the context of modern d20 games, a set piece is an adventure sequence that can be plugged in to a larger adventure, with notes offering suggestions for adapting the set piece to the genre of your particular campaign.

99339.name: Stackschach
99339.description:
Stackschach (Stacks Chess) is a Chess-like game that provides “morphing” ability to change pieces and increase or decrease the stack sizes, in order to change their ability.

This game is one in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series. Rules to the game will be available in this entry for download.

99340.name: Short Stack
99340.description:
Short Stack is a traditional stacking style game, where players move, assemble, and disassemble stacks in the game, adopted to an 8x4 game board. In Short Stack, a player's most powerful stack is always at risk of being eliminated every turn.

This game is one in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series, which are a series of games created by Richard Hutnik.

99341.name: Games International (Issue 6 – June 1989)
99341.description:
Issue 6 of Games International


Contents

Cover – Oppression

Up Front – Editorial

General Games

Reviews;

Ave Caesar
New York, New York
Maestro
Enchanted Forest
City
Targui
Der Ausresser




Out with the Turbo, In with the new – Motor racing game & variant for Speed Circuit
Holiday – Games to look for when on holiday
Convention Reports – Babbacon 89 & Gamesfair 89
The Coalfields – Variant for 1830

Abstract Games

Reviews;

Triumph
Checkmath




Wargames

Reviews;

Onslaught
La Bataille de Albuera-Espagnol
The Emperor Returns




Firefight! – Two scenarios for Platoon
Play it by Mail, Sam – Report on KJC games

Rolegames

Reviews;

The Sentinels (Robtech II)
The Fourth Succession War (Battletech)
GURPS supplements




Japan Special, Part 1 – A look at Bushido

Regulars

Quick Moves - Reviers on Rimini, Teacher's Pet, Treasure of the Incas, Stun and Willi Wacker.
R.I.P – Dallas
Desert Island Games – With James Wallis
Sniper – International gaming gossip
News
Strategy Seminar – Red Storm Rising
Rebound – Letters page
Classifieds

99342.name: Facade
99342.description:
From publisher blurb:

Façade: His good looks and playboy lifestyle lost in a fiery crash of his own making, Alain Facile is now a bitter sociopath. A bitter sociopath who can quickly change his looks to impersonate anyone, and who lives to ruin other people's lives.

99343.name: Coral Snake
99343.description:
From publisher blurb:

Coral Snake: Yvonne Orphis was born in a psychiatric hospital, and her life has been appropriately far from normal—including the ability to transform into a walking, venomous Serpent Person. The true force behind the smuggling group the Trident, Coral Snake doesn't mind letting her confederates and the rest of the world think that Trawler is the group's leader. She will gladly sell out her partners in crime to further her own goal of reclaiming her birthright as the messianic leader of the Ophidians of long-lost Lemuria. Also includes a writeup of the criminal group the Threat Report: Trident, complete with Headquarters, Vehicle, and Minions statistics.

99344.name: Steelhead
99344.description:
From publisher blurb:

Steelhead: A known smuggler and pirate, Brad Steeley is on the run after accidentally causing his father's death. His enemies are powerful, and his friends aren't as friendly as he imagines. His main assets are a sophisticated suit of stolen power armor and an impressive denial of personal responsibility. Steelhead is a member of the smuggling group the Threat Report: Trident.

99345.name: Trident
99345.description:
From publisher blurb:

Members: Threat Report #19: Coral Snake, Threat Report #20: Steelhead, and Threat Report #21: Trawler

Although the authorities tend to believe Trawler — with her history as a smuggler and dubious "salvage operator" — is the force behind the Trident, the group actually came together due to one of its other members. Coral Snake has extensively studied her Serpent heritage and the secrets of ancient Lemuria. She believes the key to greater power and control over her ophidian nature lies there, deep beneath the Pacific. To reach it, she needs help. So she came up with the smuggling scheme and recruited Trawler and Steelhead to help back it, promising Trawler a shot at the greatest treasure trove she could imagine. Forked tongue firmly in cheek, Coral Snake dubbed their new venture "the Trident".

Initially, the smuggling operation relied heavily on Trawler’s resources and the capabilities of its three founders. Success has allowed for expansion, including investment in better equipment (such as the Trident’s sea-cave hideout and "sea-serpent" submersible) and more personnel. Indeed, with the boom in illegal activities in Emerald City and the surrounding area, the Trident has more demand for contraband — particularly illegal weapons and technologies — than it can supply.

99346.name: Out of Their League
99346.description:
From "Adventure Summary:"

In this chapter of Emerald City Knights, the player characters have the opportunity to prove themselves against members of the Freedom League. Following that wonderful comic book tradition of heroes fighting each other due to a misunderstanding, the heroes find they have a sponsor and a swanky pad ready for them to move into.

Well, almost ready — the heroes get to be involved in the final stages of construction of their new base. They also get to do some relationship-building with the authorities, followed by defending their new turf from the Grandmaster’s Chessmen agents. This chapter concludes with a bit of old-school violence as the heroes stop the first set of organized stormer villains from making a name for themselves when they attack an AEGIS (the American Elite Government Intervention Service) transport.

99347.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 26 - 2005)

rpgissuearticle.117816: One the Steps of City Hall

99347.description:
From publisher blurb:

On the Steps of City Hall is the beginning of our Rising South adventure arc. These encounters are presented in a serial format for Pinebox, but we provide alternate leads and hooks to make these encounters work in other modern-world campaigns.

99348.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 27 - 2005)
99348.description:
From publisher blurb:

Sea Rescue is an adventure for Modern d20 system games. Sea Rescue pits the PCs in a race against time to save a damaged ocean liner filled with college students and requires that the PCs have access to a boat fast enough to intercept the foundering ocean liner. This adventure is designed to best suit PCs of between 6th and 9th levels though by adjusting the level of the combatants found in the adventure’s finale the adventure can accommodate a wider range of PC levels.

99349.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 28 - 2005)
99349.description:
From publisher blurb:

Rosslyn Chapel, located in a suburb of Edinburgh, Scotland, has the distinction of being one of the most reputedly conspiratorial and occult sites in the world. Although constructed over a century after the official abolition, the Chapel is popularly connected with the Knights Templar, a connection that is not without rationale. Consequently, the Chapel makes an intriguing site for adventures and campaigns revolving around occult conspiracies in the modern world.

99350.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 29 - 2005)
99350.description:
From publisher blurb:

This issue of Modern Dispatch provides Gamemasters with a series of tables with which they can generate adventure seeds for any modern d20 campaign.

The core concept of an adventure is broken into five different categories, and each category provides 64 different options -- thereby allowing this adventure generator to provide 1,073,741,824 possible adventure seeds, with each one useable in any modern d20 campaign!

99351.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 30 - 2005)
99351.description:
From publisher blurb:

Just a Few Questions is the second encounter in the adventure arc that began with On the Steps of City Hall in Modern Dispatch (Issue 26 - 2005). These encounters are presented in a serial format for the Pinebox campaign setting, but with alternate leads and hooks for use in other modern-world campaigns.

99352.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 31 - 2005)
99352.description:
From publisher blurb:

One of the most malevolent forces on the Twisted Earth is the Savant, a group of powerful psionicists whose lineage dates back to before the Fall. Once the prisoners and human guinea pigs of the Ancients, they now seek to build a new world order with themselves at the top and all others as their slaves.

From time to time, the Savant is known to conduct crusades into regions beyond their empire. Sometimes these crusades aim to eradicate the remnants of the Ancients; other times they are undertaken simply to expand their territorial control. Temple of the Savant is a Darwin's World adventure that takes place during one of these Savant crusades.

Levels: This adventure is best suited for 4-6 characters of 8-9th level. The ideal adventuring party should have healing capabilities and some members with respectable Will saves.

99353.description:
Das Book is a supplement for the Flames of War WWII miniatures game that compiles many rules and articles from several sources. It compliments the basic rule book and the similar sized starter book. Some rules are updated, such as the "No Retreat" mission which was written to be more balanced than "Hold the Line" from the main rulebook.

The compilation was credited to Casey Davies, from work by The Battlefront team and friends.

From the back cover:
Compiled from across the Flames of War book range, Das Book includes:
Nine Combat Missions: Free-For-All, Encounter, No Retreat, Fighting Withdrawl, Breakthrough, the Cauldron, Roadblock, Hasty Assault, and Breakout.
All mission special rules.
Latewar Airborne Assault Special Rules and Mission.
Bocage Rules.
River Crossing Rules and Mission.
Fortification rules, with updated bunker rules and two fortification missions: Trench Fight and The Big Push
Street Fighting rules and mission
Complete Mid and Late war Arsenals for all of the major forces.
99353.name: Flames of War: Das Book

11168.name: Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game

99354.description:
Dallifant is a game of pattern recognition for children ages 4-8.

Each player gets 5 chips (the white one is a spare), and you spread out the elephants so that everyone can see and reach them. One player rolls the two dice, and all players look for the elephant that shows the two colours that were rolled. If you spot it, place one of your chips on it. The first player's chip stays on the elephant, everyone else has to take theirs back.

If there was no chip on this elephant previously, nothing happens. If it had one of your chips on it already, both chips stay on it, and this colour combination is ignored from now on (i.e., there cannot be more than two chips on an elephant). If someone else's chip was on it, they receive their chip back and yours stays on. The next player then rolls the dice, etc.

Whoever gets rid of their 5 chips first, wins.

Two more things:
1) You can hold a chip in your hand, but not hover above the elephants before the dice are rolled.
2) It is recommended that whoever rolls the dice calls out the colours.
99354.name: Dallifant

99355.name: Sunburst City Transport
99355.description:
After another long gruelling day at your regular day job, your father calls you up with a rather urgent message. "Son, get over here right now!". Upon arrival, you find that he is unable to answer his door. Using your key, you enter the door and find him on the ground in the living room helpless and in lots of pain.

"Things are bad, son. Real bad. I seem to have herniated my disc or something. Not only that, the bank wants to foreclose on the business. I gotta come up with 6500 dollars in 55 days. Plus I think I am going to need surgery or something, and that won't be cheap. Son, ya gotta help me!!!! Take my truck and go make as much money as you can!!!"

Gameplay: The player is trying to gather enough cash to save his dad's trucking business in a 55 turns. Each turn, the player moves his truck and purchases and delivers goods. He may upgrade his business throughout the game. There are also eight big events that will affect the course of the game.

This game is my personal entry into the 2011 July/August Solitaire Print and Play Contest. I may develop a multiplayer version at a later time. It will be available for Vassal shortly.

99356.name: Scouts & Assassins (First Edition)
99356.description:
User Summary:

Scouts & Assassins includes an advanced character generation system for the Scout Service, an alternate system for early discharge from any career when a survival roll is failed, and a basic character generation system for Assassins.

It also includes an 11"x17" deck plan of the Serpent Class Type "S" Scoutship in 15mm scale, along with a four page booklet describing the ship class and the company that built it.

The book's Introduction is a fairly glowing letter from Marc W. Miller, informing all "Fellow Travellers" of Dan Rapp's great adventures, and how his work is enjoyed by several of the Workshop's design staff.

99357.name: NightSky

videogamehonor.32143: 2011 IGF Awards Excellence In Audio Nominee

99357.description:
User Summary

NightSky is a physics-based puzzle platforming game where you control a sphere through a variety of worlds and challenges. You'll navigate jumps, balance on see-saws, create bridges, power a variety of unique vehicles, and more as you progress through the game.

Features 2 difficulty levels and about 6 hours of gameplay.

99358.description:
(from MMP website:)

Stonewall Jackson’s Way II: Battles of Bull Run is the 9th game in the award-winning Great Campaigns of the American Civil War (GCACW) series. This game is actually two complete modules in one: it includes a complete revision and augmentation of Stonewall Jackson's Way (SJW; the first game in the series), and an entire new module covering the First Bull Run Campaign, called All Green Alike (AGA).

The two maps included are newly painted by original map artist Charlie Kibler and include new historical and terrain details (to bring them up to the standards of the latest games in the GCACW series).

Stonewall Jackson’s Way II: Battles of Bull Run uses the same GCACW Standard Basic Game Rules that were first published in MMP's The Skirmisher #1 and Grant Takes Command. The Advanced Game rule sets are also standardized so players will be able to move quickly from one campaign to the other.

All Green Alike: The First Bull Run Campaign, July 1861, includes four Basic Game and two Advanced Game scenarios. The Basic Game scenarios feature two Shenandoah Valley scenarios and two scenarios at Bull Run The two Advanced Game campaigns cover the advance and aftermath of the campaign.

Across the Potomac (4 turns, July 2-5, 1861)
Johnston vs. Patterson (3 turns, July 17-19, 1861)
McDowell’s Opportunity (3 turns, July 19-21, 1861)
An End to Innocence (1 turn, July 21, 1861)
The Bull Run Campaign (13 turns, July 16-28, 1861)
The Virginia Campaign (14 turns, July 15-28, 1861)




[The first and last scenarios require use of the Here Come the Rebels (the 2nd game in the GCACW series) west map (not included).]

Stonewall Jackson’s Way: Cedar Mountain to 2nd Manassas, August 1862, includes two new Basic Game scenarios, the five original Basic Scenarios redesigned and rebalanced, and the two original Advanced Game campaigns also revamped for better play balance:

Cedar Mountain (3 turns, August 8-10, 1862)
Lee vs. Pope (2 turns, August 18-19, 1862)
Stuart’s Raid (3 turns, August 22-24, 1862)
From the Rappahannock to Bull Run (6 turns, August 25-30, 1862)
Jackson’s March (3 turns, August 26-28, 1862)
Bag the Whole Crowd (3 turns, August 28-30, 1862)
Which Way Did He Go? (3 turns, August 28-30, 1862)
From the Rapidan to the Rappahannock (8 turns, August 19-26, 1862)
From the Rapidan to Manassas (15 turns, August 19 – September 2, 1862)




Stonewall Jackson’s Way II: Battles of Bull Run contains:
One 28 page GCACW Series Rules Booklet
One 68 page SJW II Specific Rules Booklet
Two 22"x 32" full-color mapsheets (North & South maps)
Three Countersheets (840 1/2" dual-side printed counters)
One Terrain Effects Chart (2 sided)
Two full-color Force Displays Cards (both 1 sided)
Two 4 page color Charts and Tables foldout
Two 6-sided Dice
99358.name: Stonewall Jackson's Way II

boardgamefamily.102: Great Campaigns of the American Civil War

99360.name: Booty for Booty Rules
99360.description:
Booty for Booty Introduction
You are the captain of a surly pirate crew, hoping you can one day get enough booty to trade it in for a mansion and a wife. Not before you've had a few more years of adventure though!

There are two Resources that the Pirates must keep track of.
Grog: The fuel of the crew. The crew begin with forty barrels of Grog.
Booty: Gold and rubies flowing out of huge chests. The crew begin with no Booty.

At the end of every week spent at sea each pirate consumes one barrel of Grog. Any pirates that do not get their barrel of Grog will immediately roll on the Sober Pirate table. A week is similar to a turn in other games.
As well as these the ship must always know it's bearing. This will be either Island or Port and may be changed at the start of any week if the pirates wish.

Winning the Game
A captain needs 300 Booty to buy a mansion and a truly impressive hat, which is the best a Pirate can hope for. Booty may be banked at any Port, where it is stored safely but may be removed by the ship's captain at any time. A new captain inherits the ship's Booty savings from the old one.

99361.name: Congo
99361.description:
Congo is a game created by the Frenchman Charles Watilliaux between 1874 and 1907. This game would have fallen into oblivion were it not for another Frenchman named Michel Boutin after a public inquiry into this game in his book: "Jeux de pions pour aujourd 'hui" in 2001 and reintroduced by Oriol Comas in his book "The World Games "
Congo is a very simple abstract strategy game with a board and a easy game mechanics.
This game tries to emulate a site on the banks of the river Congo.
4 people play and have 12 pieces each and take turns placing them anywhere on a 5x5x5 hexagonal board. The only requirement for placement is that it is not adjacent to a piece of another color, although you can play adjacent to your own color. After placing a piece, it can not be moved in any way. When a player is blocked and can not place any more pieces, they are out. The game continues until no more pieces can be played by ANY player.
When a game is complete, points are then awarded. Each player gets one point for each piece not played by a player who went out before them. Thus, 3rd place gets the points for all pieces left by 4th place, while 2nd place gets points for both 3rd and 4th place's pieces. The winner gains points from all 3 who fell by the wayside.
(Adjustment: If you allow ties in how many pieces are left over instead of "first unable not play is first out", then both people who tie gain the points of the other person they tied with.)
The best thing is to play four games, so that each player has the chance to play first.
The winner is the one with the highest cumulative score after four games.
When only two people play, it requires each player to use two colors, and each player must take into account that the two colors belonging to a player can not touch each other.


El Congo es un juego creado por el frances Charles Watilliaux entre 1874 y 1907, este juego hubiese caido en el olvido a no ser por otro frances llamado Michel Boutin que luego de una investigacion publico este juego en su libro: "Jeux de pions pour aujourd´hui" en 2001 y retomado por Oriol Comas en su libro "El Mundo en juegos"
El Congo es un juego de estrategia abstracta muy simple pero con un tablero y una mecanica muy bella. Este juego trata de emular un sitio en la orilla del rio Congo.
Jugando de a 4 personas cada jugador posee 12 fichas y las van poniendo una a una en el tablero hexagonal. La unica condicion para la colocacion es que no este adyacente a una ficha de otro color, aunque si puede estar tocando las fichas de su mismo color. Una vez colocada una ficha no se puede mover mas y no hay capturas de ningun tipo.
Cuando un jugador esta bloqueado y no puede colocar mas fichas deja de jugar, cuando el tres jugadores ya no tienen colocaciones de piezas posibles se termina la partida. En ese momento se otorgan los puntos. El primer jugador que quedo bloqueado le otorga tantos puntos como el numero de fichas que no logro colocar en el tablero a los otros 3 jugadores que continuaron jugando; el segundo bloqueado hace lo mismo con los otros dos jugadores que quedaron en carrera y por ultimo el tercer bloqueado entrega puntos al ganador del partido, es decir que el ganador recibe puntos de los otros tres jugadores que han quedado por el camino.
Lo mejor es jugar cuatro partidas, para que cada jugador tenga la posibilidad de jugar primero.
Y ganara el que tenga el mayor puntaje total de las cuatro partidas.
Para jugar de a dos personas solo se requiere que cada jugador utilice dos colores y hay que tener en cuenta por mas que los dos colores pertenezcan a un jugador igualmente no pueden tocarse entre si.

99362.name: Blowing Stuff Up Rules
99362.description:
User Summary
BSU is an action RPG which makes the unrealistic commonplace and heroism (or shameless villainy) a standard of behaviour.
It uses a dice pool mechanic somewhat similar to a Texas Hold'em (poker) game. A pool of 3 Drama Dice are combined with a pair of each character's dice and, depending on modifiers, each character succeeds or fails depending on the combination created from the dice pool.

99363.name: Five Star Chef Rules
99363.description:
User Summary
Five Star Chef is a cooking RPG where individual chefs compete by producing the best dishes through the use of their culinary talents and ingredients of varying flavour and challenge. It may be played with any number of players and does not require a game master due to the charts provided in the rules.

The rules for Five Star Chef are still in development; however, they still function.

99364.name: Inheritance Rules
99364.description:
Introduction
Inheritance is set in an age where legend and prophecy collide with an unstable world. A world of political wrangling, of shared power between the wealthy, strong and influential, all pursuing their own agendas. And to this backdrop the shields of immense armies collide at the whim of their leaders, as heroes with unique and exotic Powers clash with cunning monstrosities upon the battlefields, with force of spear and strength of will.

The players, alongside the Gamesmaster, shape these heroes and live out their legends, their Inheritance.

User Summary
Inheritance is based on the Powergame 6.05 system by Mikko Kauppinen (2002). It is intended to be as simple a system as possible, bypassing complicated roles in favor of basing almost all actions on the same scale and measuring success and failure with modified (d6) dice roles.

99365.name: Full Circle to Oblivion
99365.description:
Description from the front page of the module:

Pride, cowardice, fear and lack of faith have stripped bare the hearts of many a man of the cloth. Now all that is left is a boy, his broken father, and a village of the once damned on the edge of the Vale of Luna. The journey that started at the Flight of Fiends has come full circle and now all the chess pieces are in place. Powerful forces move in the shadows, each with their own agenda on this night of the forsaken. Which has the best interest of the Flanaess in mind and can the heroes find the right path before the shadows step into the light once again? Part Four of Five in the "To Serve the Greater Good" series. For APLs 8 - 16.

99366.name: The Letter
99366.description:
Description from the front page of the module:

Tomorrow was looking like it was going to be a quiet and peaceful day but a puzzling missive has embroiled you in a mysterious plot . . maybe two. Do you dare take on the challenge or just get out of the way as fast as possible? Either way, the Free City of Greyhawk may never be the same.
Part Two of the "Tome of Clarity and Mists" series. An adventure for APLs 2 to 12.

99367.name: A Tiger? In Ahlissa?!
99367.description:
Description from the front page of the module:

Welcome back brave adventurer to Eastfair, the Granite City, and capital of the North Kingdom. Your room at The Whirling Dervish is all ready for you as Clinorus has something important to tell you. Are you prepared to dig deeper into the cause and effect of the ritual-like murder from your last stay in Eastfair? The Hextorian government has been of little help, but perhaps you can expedite the situation through other channels. In a city where evil and tyranny rules, the forces of good are the cults, which makes justice and mercy all the more valuable as imports.
An adventure for APLs 2 - 6. Part Two of the "running with the Baatezu" series.

99368.name: Crimson Thorns
99368.description:
Description from the front page of the module:

Embassies are common in this time of tenacious and fragile peace. However, despite this peace, and the relative security it brings such embassies are always heavily guarded. Now, you have been asked to accompany one such embassy from the Free City of Dekspoint to the North Kingdom. This adventure is for parties from APL 2 through 16.
This is the First Stanza of the "Frozen Blood Saga". It is recommended that the heroes have played COR4-04 Red Tide before undertaking this adventure.

99370.name: CUBI
99370.description:
OBJECTIVE OF THE GAME:
Each teams have to achieve more points than the adversary. The score is calculated according to the table shown on last page, at the end of match. The winner is the team who builds the greater number of bigger squares, given that the score is the sum of the value of the built cubes.

SETUP THE GAME:
The players meet around the game board (ex. 4 players: Blue player, Yellow player, Blue player, Yellow player), so that they represent each player’s turn. It is a custom that the game should start with a move from the Blue team and to proceed among the players of the teams in clockwise fashion. At the beginning of the match the board has no pieces and the two teams have all their pieces yet to be played respectively.

GAMEPLAY:
Each player on his turn can make only one of these operations:
• Place of a piece;
• Move of a piece;
• Pass the turn.

CONCLUSION:
The match ends when all pieces have been placed and, therefore, the teams cannot make further moves. Interestingly, one of the teams will finish it’s pieces before the other team and so can only make the movement (or pass) waiting for the opponent team to finish its remaining pieces. This phase is called the closure of the game. During the closure the team with pieces cannot move or pass.

99371.name: A Wretched Soul
99371.description:
Description from the front page of the module:

Fresh from a peaceful sea voyage to Hardby, City of the Scorned, your prowess at derring-do is called upon. The far off jungles off Hepmonaland are your destination with their ferocious beasts and wild Olmans who sacrifice outlanders to their alien gods. What motivates the jaded adventurer to take on such a mission? The promise of coin? Assisting those with good cause? Or a chance to redeem the unredeemable? Sequel to "Though Nature to Eternity". An adventure for APLs 10 to 16.

99372.name: Sympathy for the Baatezu
99372.description:
Description from the front page of the module:

Digging deeper into the dark alleys of Eastfair has cleared up some puzzles, but the sickly dust quickly settles to create new obfuscation. Perhaps it is time to step out for some fresh air. A favour for a favour, new friends may be able to help you help yourself and get to the bottom of this mystery. With the who's and how's covered, it's time to gather up a motive. The pillows and linen are freshly changed, so head on over to The Whirling Dervish and get a good rest, you'll need it. An advrenture for APL 2 - 8. Part Three of the "running with the Baatzu" series.

99373.name: It Never Rains in Nyrond
99373.description:
Description from the front page of the module:

With the constant pressure and sorrow that Eastfair extrudes, even the most stout hearted can get the blues from time to time. But missions must be completed and duties upheld with little time left over for lamenting on greener grass. Now an old friend needs you to carry on where others have failed. A package needs to go from point A to point B, and even with a severe storm brewing, this side trip should not take you far out of the way of your own destination. Said destination being that of the instigator of all this. An adventure for APL 2 - 8. Part Four of the "Running with the Baatezu" series.

rpgitemversion.100108: That Which Was Not Meant To Be Known

99374.name: That Which Was Not Meant To Be Known
99374.description:
Description from the front page of the module:

A favour takes you from the town of Diamond Lake to the tiny village of Rowanfen on the edge of the Mistmarsh, where nothing is quite as it seems. A Core adventure set in the Domain of Greyhawk for APLs 2 to 6.

99375.name: Altanis, the Sunken City
99375.description:
From the Introduction:

This adventure is designed for a party of 6 to 9 characters from 4th to 8th levels of experience each. It is meant to be used with the rules system found in the Basic and Expert D&D books edited by TOM MOLDVAY, DAVE COOK & STEVE MARSH, from the original game created by GARY GYGAX and DAVE ARNESON. A party that intends to explore the setting of this adventure should include at least one cleric, thief and magic-user of 5th to 8th level, and several fighting men, including dwarves, elves and hobbits.

...Note that this product does not relate in any way to Judges Guild world of High Fantasy setting


User Summary:

This scenario is an unofficial extension/sequel to X1: The Isle of Dread. The scenario is set in Mystara and introduces a sunken city for the adventurers to explore.


Cover Blurb:

Myths and legends of a city beneath the waves are common gossip among seafaring folk that dwell along the coastlines of the great kingdoms. Sailors often talk of seeing mermaids far out at sea, weeks away from the sight of land. Could such creatures truly exist? Is there such a place where beings have erected an underground city? Only the most hardy and inquisitive adventurers are likely to investigate such a thing.

99376.name: All the Winners
99376.description:
48 cards in sets of four, each card in a set being numbered from 1 to 4. A noisy set collecting card game that urges you to be 'quirky' in your calls for certain cards. You literally have to make a call as if you were the street vendor yourself. The number on the card you are seeking means you have to make the shout that many times. The cards represent street vendors and this must date from after WWI because there is a striking difference between these cards and most of the publisher's other games (which were printed in Germany).
Each player is dealt a hand and if they can collect a set of four identical cards, then they can reveal them and claim a trick. The most tricks after they have all been claimed, wins.
From the rules; "A very amusing card game, ideal for children aged 7 to 70. For 3 players or more players, the more the merrier".

99377.name: A Journey to the End of the Earth
99377.description:
From the web publisher Nimble Books LLC
Even to the Russians, a hardy race with much experience at living in a cold land, swept by bitter winters, the Kola Peninsular and the Murman coast represented the very extreme of a distant, harsh and God forsaken place. Hence, they named their first colony there Murmansk. The end of the Earth.

To the Allied sailors of many nations who sailed there during WW2 it certainly seemed to live up to its name. Getting there was bad enough with all the hardships of freezing cold conditions, massive storms, and seas that could swallow up a ship leaving little trace. If forced to abandon ship in such waters they were under no illusions that they chances of survival were slim. There were some remarkable stories of survival but the privations endured by those who made it back alive were just as remarkable in that there were so few who lived to tell the tale of being sunk on the Murmansk run.

Of course, although the port facilities available were Spartan and poorly equipped to handle the huge amount of stores delivered, then there was the problem of getting such cargoes there in the first place.

Having arrived, there were almost no amenities for the crews of ships to use in order to rest up after fighting there way to Murmansk. Indeed the Soviets were reluctant to give the crews much freedom to go ashore at all. Food was scarce. That supplied was grudgingly given, boring and lacking nutrition. So for those who had arrived, the long wait until they could join a convoy back to the UK was like a prison sentence. Perhaps the only thing the Russians seemed to have plenty of was Vodka and with that they could be extremely generous.

Join the thriving community around this intensely popular war game.

Game sclae is of 20cm or 8 inches per nautical mile, so 1cm equals 1 knot. If a ship is moving 14 knots, will plot a 14 cm movement in the game, for example. Players are encouraged to play with any sclae, although the desinger suggest 1:3000 as the best one.
Players take the role of and allied convoy from or towards Murmansk or Anchangelsk during the IIWW and try to protect the ships from the German player, who will try to shunk them with either vessels, submarines or the Luftwaffe.
Game comes with a comprehensive way to generate merchants convoys and its adecuate escort of warships, meanwhile the German player will have his own forces. All this will change according to the year and nationality played, so for 1942 the forces will be different from those of 1945 and also those avaliable to the Royal Navy or the Soviets.
The game has also an event generator to add some flavor, and full tables to calculate combat and the damage and critical hits taken by the diverse forces.

99378.name: Mr. Turnip's Audition
99378.description:
This may be the first British game linked to a TV character. A card game about set collecting but with a difference. As well as the cards and rules in the box, there is a clock with movable hands.
A set is at least two cards, a Portrait card (of a character from the show) and an Audition card (with a time on it). Thus you can only claim a trick if the Time element is the same as the clock currently shows.
The clock starts at 9.00 a.m.. The first player may lay down a set if he also has the correct time. Then the second player has the same opportunity, and so on round the table. However, if a player does not have a set to display, he draws a card from the deck and the clock is moved on one hour. Now the next player has to have a set that includes the new time, and so on.

boardgamehonor.12413: 2011 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "3 years and up" Nominee

99379.description:
Kleine Froschmusik is an educational game of memory and singing.

All frog-cards (with frogs in different colours or water lilies) are arranged in a circle face down. Players by turn roll a dice and according to the roll either exchange positions of frog-cards or try to turn up a card with a water lily or a frog in the corresponding colour. If the players turns up the correct card, he gets another turn.

As soon as a player reveals the third frog, he draws a concert-card. This cards show frogs in different posture / height. Players than sing a melody according to the sequence of the frogs (for example arms up = high-pitched, squatting = low-pitched). Then the player who turned up the third frog gets the concert-card as his score.

The first player to have 3 concert-cards is the winner.
99379.name: Kleine Froschmusik

99380.name: Moshi Monsters
99380.description:
Moshi Monsters is a new free online game for girls and boys where you can create your very own virtual pet and care for it online with your friends.

Each virtual pet has a lively, unique personality that develops the more you play and care for your online pet.

Earn money by playing fun puzzle games, and use these rewards to go shopping to buy new items to dress and customize your pet.

Remember, your pet Moshi needs love, so don't forget to feed your Moshi regularly to keep it healthy and happy!

Alternatively you may want to reward your cyber pet by dressing it up or buying new items to customize your very own pet’s home.
Play the FREE online cyber pet game for kids that is taking the world by storm! Create your free online virtual pet and join the Moshi revolution NOW!

Source: The Game Website.

99382.name: Agents of S.W.I.N.G.
99382.description:
From publisher blurb:

Agents of SWING is a FATE-powered Spy-Fi adventure game in which you take on the part of secret agents, working throughout the world in the 1960s and 70s to avert catastrophe, punish evildoers and stop the two superpowers from annihilating each other.

A slimmed down and sped up version of FATE, derived from Cubicle 7's Starblazer Adventures, SWING simplifies the system and lets you get right into the action.

There are rules for agents, villains, henchmen and goons. There are rules for coming up with nefarious organisations, hints and tips on how to run the game (including a 'plot stress' adventure structure) and a ton of starting level PCs so that you can pick up and play right out of the book.

A hit during playtesting at UK conventions, now you can finally get your hands on Agents of SWING and start laying into the enemies of humanity.

Just do it with STYLE.

99383.name: Agent Casefile
99383.description:
From publisher blurb:

An agent's casefile with reference tables, character sheets and room for casenotes.

99384.name: Control Casefile
99384.description:
From publisher blurb:

A work-booklet for Control to use in Agents of SWING to plan plots, reference rules and wrangle the stats of villains, henchmen and goons.

Reference sheets for the GM in Agents of SWING along with tracking sheets for goons, villains and henchmen.

Contains errata for the first printing of Agents of SWING.

99385.name: Milton Keynes
99385.description:
Milton Keynes is a not-very-politically-correct strategy board game for 2 to 5 players. Combining elements of topology & connectivity, empire-building, bidding, bluffing and trading, it delivers a fun and thoughtful gaming experience time and time again.

Collect income from your buildings to buy land from farmers and make "campaign contributions" to local politicians, a necessity for obtaining decent plots. Buildings with many neighbours fetch more rent so don't be the first to build in the middle of nowhere! Political influence might let you play dirty tricks on your opponents. Don't be too surprised if they return the favour though.

99386.name: The Wheelman
99386.description:
From Introduction:

There are some very good reasons why Leverage the show doesn’t feature a wheelman, or indeed many moving vehicles at all. As a game of the show, that provides a very compelling reason not to include the archetype in the game. On the other hand, maybe you’re not playing an exact copy of Leverage. Maybe you’re playing some other kind of heist show, where driving isn’t just a handy way to change scenes, but is the bread and butter to your heroes. Or at least, the heart and soul of one of your main characters. In that case, you’re going to need this... – Steve Darlington, May, 2011


The Wheelman

Ultimately, all jobs are about movement. The Grifters and Masterminds work their magic so at the right moment, everyone is looking the wrong way and then something is either moved out or in. Hackers can move information; Thieves can move a suitcase, a data stick, maybe an extra body. Soon enough, however, you’re going to run into an issue of volume: sometimes, you need to move a lot of something, or a big something. That might be the goal of the job, other times you might just need to bring in a howitzer, or a crane, or an elephant for some part of the scheme. And when you need that kind of volume, you need a Wheelman.

You can read the whole thing here: http://tinstargames.weebly.com/stuff-for-leverage-the-role-p...

99387.name: Suitcase Full of Cash
99387.description:
User summary:

A collection of pregen characters culled from films and shows such as "Burn Notice," The Usual Suspects and Madagascar - as well as some originals - as well as new Talents.

This game is available as a free download from Tin*Games (see link at bottom of page.)

99388.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 32 - 2005)
99388.description:
From publisher blurb:

This issue of the Modern Dispatch features Deadline, Inc., the military arm of a company that has holdings in gas, oil, and minerals. It considers itself to be a military consultancy, and it purports to specialize in advice and problem resolution for legitimate governments. It is an independent entity, but its senior officers are former military personnel from several major nations.

99389.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 33 - 2005)
99389.description:
From publisher blurb:

This issue of the Modern Dispatch details The Order of Saint Lucian, a secret organization within the Vatican, that, depending upon the needs of your campaign, can be used as either the Vatican's secret service, a cabal of fanatical assassins (perfect villains for a conspiratorial campaign), or a secret order dedicated to combatting the forces of Evil!

The issue includes the history of the order, and an overview, adventure hooks and a sample NPC for each campaign option.

99390.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 34 - 2005)
99390.description:
From publisher blurb:

Party Crashers is the third and final encounter in the adventure arc that began with On the Steps of City Hall in Modern Dispatch (Issue 26 - 2005) and continued with Just a Few Questions in Modern Dispatch (Issue 30 - 2005). These encounters are presented in a serial format for the Pinebox campaign setting, but with alternate leads and hooks for use in other modern-world campaigns.

99391.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 36 - 2005)
99391.description:
From publisher blurb:

Eight alien artifacts for use with futuristic campaigns in this Modern Dispatch issue, including both background information and game statistics these artifacts are ready for action in your next campaign. Enough information is included to inspire the GM -- each artifact can be used as the basis for an adventure.

99392.description:
Colonial: Europe's Empires Overseas is a board game about colonial times, from the Renaissance to the Industrial Revolution.

In Colonial players are the rulers of mighty European states and send their ministers to explore the earth, establish missions, ascertain scientific supremacy, and trade in exotic goods. These commodities will have to be exploited on an industrial scale and resold in Europe or in the colonies.

Set against an epic historical backdrop and using a branded Character Card-driven system, conventional dice and custom dice, this fast-paced board game requires careful management, knowledge, diplomacy and a degree of luck to lead to victory in the race for prestige.
99392.name: Colonial: Europe's Empires Overseas

99393.name: Kapteeni ja pilssihiiri
99393.description:
Based on the books of beloved Finnish childrens author Mauri Kunnas, Kapteeni ja pilssihiiri ("Captain and the bilge rat") is a roll and move game where players try to get their three pawns to complete a circuit around the board.

Movement is color-coded: red symbol on a die means the red pawn moves to the next red tile, blue moves blue and so on. There are also arrows that let players remove tiles from play. This has two effects: it makes the circuit shorter as players skip over removed tiles and it can also remove a pawn from play, trapping a player until she can return the tile in play.

99394.name: Games International (Issue 7 – July 1989)
99394.description:
Issue 7 of Games International


Contents

Cover – The Glog Game

Up Front – Editorial

General Games

Reviews;

Share Mania
The Really Nasty Horse Racing Game
The Great Khan Game
Oppression




The Big Heap – A report on TSRs Partyzone game, The Inheritance
Indiscretion – Five new games for Indiscretion
Convention Reports – Hexacon III & Campaign 89
Nuclear Risk! – A variant using Risk and Nuclear War
Viva Mexico! – An expansion for Empire Builder

Abstract Games

Reviews;

Quadromania
Axiom
Stack




Wargames

Reviews;

Last Battle




Landing at Calais – Onslaught variant
Tally Ho! – A look at Air Wargames

Rolegames

Reviews;

Transdimiensional TMNT
Conklin’s Atlas (Space 1889)




Japan Special, Part 2 – A look at other Japanese background RPGs

Regulars

R.I.P – Trade
Desert Island Games – With Derek Carver
Sniper – International gaming gossip
News
Strategy Seminar – Imperium Romanum II
Rebound – Letters page
Classifieds

99395.name: Pyramid (Volume 3, Issue 24 - Oct 2010)
99395.description:
Bio-Tech

From the publisher:

This month's issue of Pyramid -- the PDF magazine for roleplayers -- celebrates life . . . with bio-tech! This futuristic folio features:


"Biomecha," a guide to powerful, living, organic battlesuits. This article -- written by GURPS Bio-Tech co-author and fan-favorite David Pulver -- includes a full overview of this anime-style genre, campaign ideas, and sample GURPS templates and guidelines. These mighty morphing mortal mecha will really grow on you!
"Martian Tech," a collection of new biological equipment fresh from the Red Planet. Designed to work with the Roma Universalis alternate Earth presented in Pyramid #3/20: Infinite Worlds, this material can be useful to any campaign that features alien or unusual biological equipment.
"Better Living Through Pharmaceuticals," featuring 10 new drugs that build on material from GURPS Bio-Tech. Written by Pyramid editor Steven Marsh, these drugs will speed you up, knock you down, and plug you into strange and alien life.
"Terra Incognita: Adleman Bank," a strange encounter with someone who goes beyond living at his office! It includes GURPS stats for this unusual entity.
"The Children of Inzanami," a campaign framework that brings bioengineering to the stars, resulting in strange "creatures" having more in common with humanity than anyone knows . . .


In addition, Pyramid also provides lots of bits that make a magazine fun: a new character sheet that's ideal for those with biomods, cyberware, and other body-part-specific oddities; Murphy's Rules with Greg Hyland; Steven Marsh's Random Thought Table; and other odds and ends. Let's face facts: If you're alive, you need this issue!

99396.name: Conflicting Kingdoms
99396.description:
Conflicting Kingdoms is essentially a board game where you choose an avatar as your main playing character and you use it to move across the board to engage in battle and defeat your enemies.

But this is unlike any board game you have played before. It uses the unique method of deck building as used in trading card games like Magic the Gathering and Yu Gi Oh. You play the cards from your deck to build the board you play on and you also use the cards to buff your avatar and to weaken your enemies with ability cards.

99397.name: Boston! The Broken Cradle of Liberty
99397.description:
Publisher Blurb

NOT ALL CITIES ARE CREATED EQUAL...
One of the hottest Hot Spots of North America, Boston was saved from the encroaching seas by a massive civic undertaking, and declared the capital of Atlantica. Now, in the face of riots and acts of terrorism, the American 'Cradle of Liberty' reels under martial law as dissidents protest unpopular decisions in an effort to stoke the flames of rebellion. With soldiers patrolling the streets and violence a way of life, Boston stands poised to either blossom into something greater or be wiped off the map and into oblivion.

SOMETIMES YOU'VE GOTTA MAKE 'EM THAT WAY!
Boston: The Broken Cradle of Liberty has everything you need to take your campaign into the highways and byways of Boston. Whether you're a GM who wants to know what's going on in Beantown, or a player who just wants to hail from the area, you'll have everything you need to know to add Boston to your game. So grab your handy Watchdog and a Molotov Cocktail, tomo, and help decide the direction of the new revolution!

IN THIS BOOK YOU'LL FIND:
-Tons of information about Boston, including neighborhoods, interesting locations and some of the major players of the city.
-New Edges, Hindrances and Occupations to help give your character that Beantown feel, as well as a whole mess of new gear popular to Boston, courtesy of Malmart.
-New rules for city Trappings, to help give locations a unique feel.
-Random gang generation tables!
-Two complete Savage Tales, and a half-dozen plot hooks to get your Boston campaign rolling.
-Stats for the important (and some of the not-so-important) characters in Boston.

This is an expansion for Interface Zero (Savage Worlds), and not a stand-alone setting.

99398.name: BattleTechnology: The Early Years (Special Edition 1995)
99398.description:
Front cover art: Frederic Kuramura
Back cover art: Aaron Froke

Contents

What Really Happened?
The Ghost of the Twenty Fifth
The Liao Protocol
MechWarriors Tell Their Tales
Hiring Hall
More Than Warriors
World Book

Special Bonus Section!
A Day in the Life of the Inner Sphere: October 21, 3013

BattleTac
BattleTech Simulator
Know Your Supplier
__________________________

99399.description:
The first expansion to the popular States of Siege game, Legions of Darkness. The Book of Magic introduces new spells, guardians (a new type of hero), and enemy bosses to wreak havoc on the defenders of your castle. There's even talk of a necromancer who walks the land, raising the dead to fight against the castle.
Plenty of new things await you in the Legions of Darkness expansion #1: Book of Magic!

Note, the Legions of Darkness Expansion Kit 1: Book of Magic is not a ‘stand alone’ game. You must own a copy of Legions of Darkness to use this expansion kit.

Game Data:

Complexity: 2.5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 9 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each unit represents one Dark Legion, each turn represents a few hours, and each space represents several meters.

Game Components:

• One two-page full color rules sheet
• 12 Event Cards (8 Day and 4 Night cards)
• 13 double-sided 5/8" round markers
99399.name: Legions of Darkness Expansion Kit 1: Book of Magic

99402.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Through force and diplomatic guile the Shōgunate has taken to the mainland. Divisions of Ashigaru march against the enemies of the Shōgun Hatamoto, while highly trained agents of the elusive "Shin" use the cover of darkness to accomplish their goals.

The Shōgunate Troop Pack for Tannhäuser includes one painted Ashigaru figure and one Shin Agent figure, each with character sheets. This, along with 24 game tokens, 17 equipment cards, and a 12-page rulebook with an included scenario, lets you add these versatile killers to your Reich or Shōgunate team.
99402.name: Tannhäuser: Shogunate Troop Pack

99403.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Tactical genius, diplomat, servant to the Imperial Throne... the dossier on Iroh Minamoto, often referred to as "the Daimyo", continues to grow. No matter how many times he is defeated, Iroh and his katana continue to return to the battlefield, unperturbed and ready for another fight.

This single miniature pack for Tannhäuser – Iroh – contains one painted Iroh figure with a character sheet, 12 game tokens, 11 equipment cards, and a 12-page rulebook that includes a dedicated scenario! Add him to your Reich team, or let him lead your Shōgunate forces into battle!
99403.name: Tannhäuser: Iroh

99404.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 37 - 2005)
99404.description:
From publisher blurb:

This issue of Modern Dispatch is a preview exerpt of the Thrilling Tales product, Pulp Villains: Nazis - and provides Modern D20 statistics for the weapons and vehicles used by the Third Reich during the pulp era of the 1930s!

From the Luger P-08 to the Maschinengewehr 34, and from the Panzerkampfwagen III to the huge, graceful Zeppelins, this issue of Modern Dispatch is a valuable resource for Modern D20 GMs.

99405.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 38 - 2005)
99405.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Big Thicket of East Texas is one of the last remaining jungle-like regions of North America. Its dense undergrowth is so thick in places that it cannot be penetrated without a sharp machete or hatchet. Every deer season, many hunters find themselves lost within its confines. In East Texas it is often said, "Stay within 20 feet of the road or you’ll get lost — and you may never be found again!"

Many legends involving the Thicket persist even today: bigfoot and panther sightings, rumors of chupacabra attacks, reports of ghostly Spanish soldiers, fierce Native American spirits, and tales of buried Confederate Hope Gold. Some even say that pirates from Galveston ventured up the Sabine River to hide their loot in the deep woods. Other phenomena are also common, ranging from unexplained lights in the night sky to strange disappearances, bizarre and dangerous weather patterns, and the mysterious Flames of Kirby Smith. In the Pinebox Campaign all of these legends are true, and they make for great side treks or short adventures. Three such side treks are presented in this
issue of Modern Dispatch: The Beasts of the Thicket, Little Lost Child, and Last Chance Gold.

99406.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 39 - 2005)
99406.description:
From publisher blurb:

Dragons are a staple of roleplaying fantasy. Few menaces have been more explored or detailed than the dragon. For modern d20 players who enjoy occult and conspiracy themed campaigns, the dragon represents a wealth of mythology with which to develop a secret society campaign model. Using the secret society rules presented in Blood and Relics (2nd Edition), this dispatch article outlines a modern horror campaign model based on the traditional concepts of fantasy roleplaying dragons.

The conspiracy at the heart of Blood and Relics is focused on the Blood War between the Sang Real and the Caeder. Blood and Dragons also involves a secret war - one revolving around secret societies created to protect the bloodlines of ancient wyrms. This hidden struggle pits two factions against each other: one group that follows the evil, colored dragon bloodlines (black, blue, green, red, and white) and another which follows the good, metallic bloodlines (brass, bronze, copper, gold, and silver).

99407.description:
Everybody has issues! Maybe things would be different if you didn't spend so much time on the phone (or at the bar; or at the mall; or in the gym...)You might even be able to spend some time, you know, fighting for your life!

Zombies!!! X adds a whole new level of complication to the Zombies!!! board game. Now, not only do you have to worry about your brains being eaten by the zombies, you also have to remember to: Feed the Addiction!

This expansion for the Zombies!!! board game adds: • 15 map tiles • 30 event cards • Rules • 6 copies of the "Addiction" cards!!!
99407.name: Zombies!!! X: Feeding the Addiction

99408.name: Omatako
99408.description:
In this tactical spatial two player game, played on a 3 x 3 field, each player has eight playing pieces: 2x2, 2x3, 2x4 and 2x6 movement points (printed on the top of the pieces). The goal is to be on top of two equally tall stacks of four or five pieces in height.
Players start on their side of the field, bringing in their pieces, which move the number of movement points printed on them. A movement point can be spend horizontally or vertically, as when a piece climbs up on top of another piece (or a stack of them) or down. Only the pieces on top of a stack may move, everything below them is blocked.
The first player to top two stacks of four or two of five pieces in height is the winner.

The game is named after two similar looking mountains in Namibia.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

99409.name: Raus aus dem Schneckenhaus
99409.description:
Raus aus dem Schneckenhaus (translation: Out of the Snailhouse) is a simple roll-and-move game with some special cards, where you have to collect (visit) all different coloured spaces, before you are allowed to exit the track. If you exit the track without having collected all the different colours, you are forced to lose one colour and start the track at the beginning again.

This is a very rare game which only had 200 copies produced and only 10 were ever sold.

99413.name: The Handbook of Arcane Artifacts
99413.description:
From the back cover:

Even from a distance, the ruins of the Evil One's fortress appeared forboding, yet your band of seasoned adventurers continued to cautiously approach. It was night fall, and you had all agreed that it would be best to enter under the cover of darkness. Your mission was simple - slay the remaining numbers of the Evil One's minions so the village of Bakers Piont could sleep comfortably at night without having their virgin daughters abducted. In return, they agreed to forget a certain indiscretion of one of your more light-fingered party members who was awaiting execution in their jail, and the 100gp each that they had agreed to pay you did not sound bad either.

You approached the front gates without incident. After sorting through the rubble in the collapsed tower, you discovered a trap door with stairs descending beneath. Following them, you soon entered a subterranean level of the fortress. After several hours of exploring, your group was ambushed by the minions of evil! The insuing battle was long and bloody. When you finally managed to slay the last of them and searched the area, you discovered their hidden treasure hoard.

The chest was trapped, and it cost you the life of a party member. Inside, you found a small box with a latch, a pouch made of an unusual hide holding 10 stones bearing strange markings, a vial of green ointment, a pair of jet black gloves, a bottle marked Brandy, and a sword with an imp carved in it's handle. As you examined the sword, you thought the imp blinked his eyes...

99414.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Add the speed and power of the "Tank Busters" to your Dust Tactics forces! These new Allied soldiers seem to be a contradiction; despite their heavy combat armor they are able to move across the battlefield at lightning fast speed. The Tank Busters' specialty is to function as highly effective anti-armor units.

Each member is equipped with a reactor-fueled bazooka that can waste enemy armored vehicles. Take advantage of their phenomenal speed to reach an enemy walker no matter where it hides; they are able to ignore obstacles in their path by flying over them! Should their bazookas fail them, these unbelievably strong individuals can punch through a walker's armor during close combat.
99414.name: Dust Tactics: Heavy Ranger Tank Hunter Squad – "Tank Busters"

99415.description:
Game description from the publisher:
In the wake of Germany's invasion of Stalingrad, where hundreds of thousands of soldiers had been lost or grievously injured, the Axis leaders turned to the extremes of science. From the labs of the Blutkreuz Korps comes a horrific solution: Wiederbeleben Serum. When this elixir is injected into the corpses of fallen soldiers, it not only reanimates them but grants them incredible resilience. With the Axis Zombies, the Axis now has plenty of new troops for the front lines.

Despite their simple minds, the Blutkreuz Korps needs these undead soldiers to focus on only one objective, annihilating the enemy. With their Fast ability, the Axis Zombies can easily close in on their targets. Allied commanders will need to adapt quickly to these new enemies as they are both mindlessly fearless and sometimes appear impervious to gunfire.
99415.name: Dust Tactics: Blutkreuz Korps Untertoten Squad – "Axis Zombies"

99416.name: Dyson's Dodecahedron (Volume 1, Issue 4 - May 2011)
99416.description:
Editorial introduction:

Erdea Manor is a Labyrinth Lord adventure location for a party of level 3 to 6 characters, expecting an average level of 4.5. This issue contains the first two of four levels of the Manor, the remaining two levels will be released in Issue 5, hopefully in the next couple of weeks.

While Erdea Manor was written for Labyrinth Lord, it also has a few monsters from the Advanced Edition Companion—you will need said volume for the quasits and some spell effects found herein.

99417.name: Polyhedron (Issue 135 - Vol. 19, No. 2)

rpgissuearticle.53866: City Stories: The Temple of Gond

99417.description:
Cover art: Illustrator Hannibal King gets retro with his Dieties and Demigods homage.

This issue had a religion theme, including the credits page, which listed The Cathedral, Cardinal, Bishop, Missionaries, Choir, and Altar Boy instead of the normal titles (publisher, editor, etc.).

Featured articles:
